issue.title: Visualization
issue.body:
This is to collect work-in-progress information on speed-JSON file visualization.

Current version accessible at https://test.openquantumsafe.org/performance.html

Feedback/improvement suggestions by @dstebila :
- [X] add a few more default filters, such as Level 1/3/5
- [X] filter out CPA algorithms
- [X] remove OQSKEM/SIGDEFAULT algorithms
- [X] color as in https://csrc.nist.gov/CSRC/media/Presentations/the-2nd-round-of-the-nist-pqc-standardization-proc/images-media/moody-opening-remarks.pdf#page=15
- [ ] labels close the relevant data: Check out https://stackoverflow.com/questions/35022830/chart-js-change-label-orientation-on-x-axis-for-line-charts#39706986 Alternative: Leave current tooltip labelling.
- [X] include information about the experimental setup
- [X] put the keygen, encaps, decaps graphs one after each other then to give enough space
- [X] add timeseries option

comment.body: @dstebila Please check (again) https://test.openquantumsafe.org/speed_kem_series.html: It now implements pretty much all of your proposals/suggestions. I left in some old data to document my stupidity properly selecting AWS CPU resources (and to make the graphs look cute :-). If OK, I'll then proceed to refactor the code such that all visualizations get this new logic.

issue.title: Merged upstream 1.1.1h tag
issue.body:
Merged upstream [1.1.1h tag](https://github.com/openssl/openssl/tree/OpenSSL_1_1_1h).

Re-ran `make generate_crypto_objects` because this version introduced new OIDs.

comment.body:
@dstebila, @xvzcf, @baentsch; could you test this merge (especially on downstream projects/demos), to make sure there are no side effects (the merge was non-trivial).

Appveryor tests haven't been enabled yet (blocked by #237), so the test failure is expected.

issue.title: Fixed SIKE p751 in alg doc.
issue.body: Updated SIKE p751 security level in algorithm's documentation.

issue.title: Undefined behaviour in SIKE compressed
issue.body:
When enabling clang's UndefinedBehaviorSanitizer using the build sequence
```
mkdir build && cd build
cmake -DCMAKE_C_COMPILER=clang-9 -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Debug -DUSE_SANITIZER=Undefined -GNinja ..
ninja
```
there are several undefined behaviours identified in the SIKE compressed code.  The log is below:

```
root@8995fd9c66df:~/liboqs/build# tests/test_kem SIKE-p434-compressed
Configuration info
==================
Target platform:  x86_64-Linux-4.19.76-linuxkit
Compiler:         clang (9.0.0 (tags/RELEASE_900/final))
OQS version:      0.2.1-dev
Git commit:       b3ca583e00ceafc800cf0c1f75d4965bdc627b22
OpenSSL enabled:  Yes (OpenSSL 1.1.1  11 Sep 2018)
AES:              OpenSSL
SHA-2:            OpenSSL
SHA-3:            OpenSSL
CFLAGS:            -fvisibility=hidden -Werror -Wall -Wextra -Wpedantic -Wimplicit -Wunused -Wcomment -Wchar-subscripts -Wuninitialized -Wstrict-prototypes -Wshadow -Wformat-security -Wwrite-strings -ggdb3 -fcolor-diagnostics -Wno-missing-braces

================================================================================
Sample computation for KEM SIKE-p434-compressed
================================================================================
../src/kem/sike/P434/../compression/dlog.c:108:35: runtime error: index 4 out of bounds for type 'const f2elm_t' (aka 'felm_t const[2]')
../src/kem/sike/P434/../compression/dlog.c:96:39: runtime error: index 330 out of bounds for type 'const f2elm_t' (aka 'felm_t const[2]')
../src/kem/sike/P434/../compression/dlog.c:98:39: runtime error: index 330 out of bounds for type 'const f2elm_t' (aka 'felm_t const[2]')
../src/kem/sike/P434/../compression/dlog.c:115:35: runtime error: index 4 out of bounds for type 'const f2elm_t' (aka 'felm_t const[2]')
../src/kem/sike/P434/../compression/dlog.c:65:34: runtime error: index 4 out of bounds for type 'const f2elm_t' (aka 'felm_t const[2]')
../src/kem/sike/P434/../compression/dlog.c:58:38: runtime error: index 8 out of bounds for type 'const f2elm_t' (aka 'felm_t const[2]')
shared secrets are equal
root@8995fd9c66df:~/liboqs/build# tests/test_kem SIKE-p503-compressed
Configuration info
==================

Compiler:         clang (9.0.0 (tags/RELEASE_900/final))

================================================================================
Sample computation for KEM SIKE-p503-compressed
================================================================================

../src/kem/sike/P503/../compression/dlog.c:96:39: runtime error: index 930 out of bounds for type 'const f2elm_t' (aka 'felm_t const[2]')

comment.body:
A fix for the reported warnings is provided at 
https://github.com/microsoft/PQCrypto-SIDH/pull/33/commits/9e362333afa5414179334207ffe29c34f3d9de64

issue.title: Figure out how to integrate KEMs into EVP layer

comment.body:
https://github.com/openssl/openssl/pull/13018 is extending the work done in changes recently merged for OpenSSL 3.0:
- https://github.com/openssl/openssl/pull/12750 added support for KEM at the `EVP` layer, backed by implementations provided by internal or external OpenSSL Providers
- https://github.com/openssl/openssl/pull/11914 allowed OpenSSL Providers to "plug in" groups (even custom ones) to be used by `libssl` for _key exchange_ in TLSv1.3

https://github.com/openssl/openssl/pull/13018 would extend https://github.com/openssl/openssl/pull/11914 to:
- add an extra capability to allow providers to optionally signal that a "plugged-in" group behaves as a KEM (_key encapsulation method_),
- include minimal changes in `libssl` to act on this optional capability:
  - handling of the `Key Share` extension on the client and the server checks the new capability so that, if set to true, the API introduced in https://github.com/openssl/openssl/pull/12750 is called, _as an alternative to the traditional "DH-like scheme", that remains unchanged_.  

The combination of these 2 items would allow OpenSSL Providers to model the "plugged-in" groups either under the _key exchange_ scheme (both sides do a Diffie-Hellman_-like_ exchange) or the _key encapsulation method_ scheme (client sends KEM pubkey in `Key Share`, server encapsulates under given pubkey and send back the ciphertext as its `Key Share`, client decapsulates the received ciphertext using the paired privkey).
Given that a _key exchange_ scheme can trivially be described as a KEM scheme, this also allows the authors of OpenSSL Providers to optionally describe DH-like primitives in terms of KEM, which also simplifies the design and deployment of [hybrid schemes][id/tls-hybrid] composing _traditional-computing-resistant_ and _quantum-computing-resistant_ primitives.

  
https://github.com/openssl/openssl/pull/13018 is currently held back, because it is coming quite late in the development cycle of the OpenSSL 3.0 release and because we all want to avoid "feature creep".

I presented [my argument for inclusion][pro-inclusion] nonetheless and I am [looking for endorsement][call-for-comments] by members of the community to build support for it: please consider participating in the https://github.com/openssl/openssl/pull/13018 discussion if you want to show your support on the matter, caution against inclusion, or share any relevant feedback.

[pro-inclusion]: https://github.com/openssl/openssl/pull/13018#issuecomment-700978207
[call-for-comments]: https://github.com/openssl/openssl/pull/13018#issuecomment-700979119
[id/tls-hybrid]: https://github.com/dstebila/draft-ietf-tls-hybrid-design

issue.title: Collect input to discuss/ease upstream uptake
issue.body: The goal of this fork is to eventually enable/ease QSC uptake into OpenSSL. This issue should serve as a focus/collection point for "challenge areas" we see in the design/APIs/data structures, e.g., along the lines of issues #59 or #214 that we may want to bring up with upstream maintainers.

comment.body:
I think this issue might also benefit from including the same update I posted on #59 :

> https://github.com/openssl/openssl/pull/13018 is extending the work done in changes recently merged for OpenSSL 3.0:
> - https://github.com/openssl/openssl/pull/12750 added support for KEM at the `EVP` layer, backed by implementations provided by internal or external OpenSSL Providers
> - https://github.com/openssl/openssl/pull/11914 allowed OpenSSL Providers to "plug in" groups (even custom ones) to be used by `libssl` for _key exchange_ in TLSv1.3
> 
> https://github.com/openssl/openssl/pull/13018 would extend https://github.com/openssl/openssl/pull/11914 to:
> - add an extra capability to allow providers to optionally signal that a "plugged-in" group behaves as a KEM (_key encapsulation method_),
> - include minimal changes in `libssl` to act on this optional capability:
>   - handling of the `Key Share` extension on the client and the server checks the new capability so that, if set to true, the API introduced in https://github.com/openssl/openssl/pull/12750 is called, _as an alternative to the traditional "DH-like scheme", that remains unchanged_.  
> 
> The combination of these 2 items would allow OpenSSL Providers to model the "plugged-in" groups either under the _key exchange_ scheme (both sides do a Diffie-Hellman_-like_ exchange) or the _key encapsulation method_ scheme (client sends KEM pubkey in `Key Share`, server encapsulates under given pubkey and send back the ciphertext as its `Key Share`, client decapsulates the received ciphertext using the paired privkey).
> Given that a _key exchange_ scheme can trivially be described as a KEM scheme, this also allows the authors of OpenSSL Providers to optionally describe DH-like primitives in terms of KEM, which also simplifies the design and deployment of [hybrid schemes][id/tls-hybrid] composing _traditional-computing-resistant_ and _quantum-computing-resistant_ primitives.
> 
>   
> https://github.com/openssl/openssl/pull/13018 is currently held back, because it is coming quite late in the development cycle of the OpenSSL 3.0 release and because we all want to avoid "feature creep".
> 
> I presented [my argument for inclusion][pro-inclusion] nonetheless and I am [looking for endorsement][call-for-comments] by members of the community to build support for it: please consider participating in the https://github.com/openssl/openssl/pull/13018 discussion if you want to show your support on the matter, caution against inclusion, or share any relevant feedback.
> 
> [pro-inclusion]: https://github.com/openssl/openssl/pull/13018#issuecomment-700978207
> [call-for-comments]: https://github.com/openssl/openssl/pull/13018#issuecomment-700979119
> [id/tls-hybrid]: https://github.com/dstebila/draft-ietf-tls-hybrid-design
>

issue.title: Undefined behaviour in SIKE compressed
issue.body:
When enabling clang's UndefinedBehaviorSanitizer using the build sequence
```
mkdir build && cd build
cmake -DCMAKE_C_COMPILER=clang-9 -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Debug -DUSE_SANITIZER=Undefined -GNinja ..
ninja
```
there are several undefined behaviours identified in the SIKE compressed code.  The log is below:

```
root@8995fd9c66df:~/liboqs/build# tests/test_kem SIKE-p434-compressed
Configuration info
==================
Target platform:  x86_64-Linux-4.19.76-linuxkit
Compiler:         clang (9.0.0 (tags/RELEASE_900/final))
OQS version:      0.2.1-dev
Git commit:       b3ca583e00ceafc800cf0c1f75d4965bdc627b22

Sample computation for KEM SIKE-p434-compressed
================================================================================
